summary: This is an attorney proffer dated January 3, 2020, detailing a client's account of her relationship with Jeffrey Epstein from April 2004 to February 2007. It describes the initial contact, the nature of their interactions, Epstein's associates and employees, the client's role in introducing other girls, and her eventual disillusionment. The document provides significant insight into Epstein's operations, recruitment methods, and inner circle. This is an attorney proffer letter dated January 3, 2020, from attorney Jeffrey S. Pop. It outlines his client's perception of Jeffrey Epstein's systematic methods for manipulating and exploiting young women, detailing a 16-point pattern of control, sexual exploitation, and eventual discard.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the document, described as a self-made billionaire with a sexual fetish who recruited young women for massages and sexual activities, and pressured them to introduce other girls.

persons.name: Mila
persons.context: A woman approximately 25 years old who informed the client about Epstein, stating he paid $300 for a topless massage and would masturbate. She connected the client to Barbara.

persons.name: Barbara
persons.context: A contact from Paris, a model and aspiring hair stylist living in Harlem, who met the client at Starbucks, critiqued her, and confirmed details about Epstein, including that he might help with clothes and school.

persons.name: Jean Luc Brunel
persons.role: Modeling Agency Owner/Close Friend of Epstein
persons.context: A close friend of Epstein for over 10 years, believed to be an owner/part-owner of Karin Modeling (later MC2). Lived at an address where Epstein owned apartments for staff and associates. Allegedly brought Brazilian models.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as intimidating, the 'original girl finder' who helped coordinate supplies at Epstein's island. The client felt she was domineering and aggressive, and tried to stay away from her.

persons.name: Eva Dubin
persons.context: An ex-girlfriend of Epstein; her daughter was Epstein's goddaughter. Epstein cared for her and visited her home before going to jail.

persons.name: Faith Kates
persons.context: Owner of Next Model Management, a friend of Epstein since the 1990s. Introduced the client to Epstein around 2005 and was asked by Epstein to introduce him to girls.

persons.name: Sarah Groff
persons.context: Epstein's executive secretary, described as his 'right hand' at the office, in charge of his call list and travel arrangements. Polite, neutral, and invaluable to Epstein.

persons.name: Nadia
persons.context: Epstein's personal assistant who handled travel, packing, shopping, and restocking. Described as calm, quiet, friendly, and reserved. Believed by the client to potentially be a victim of Epstein.

persons.name: Adriana
persons.context: Office assistant to Epstein from 2004-2006, senior to the client. Originally from Sweden, introduced to Epstein by Eva Dubin. Left in early 2006 to move to Dubai.

persons.name: Ania
persons.context: A 21-year-old model from Poland who became a second assistant to Epstein. Epstein was obsessed with her body. She left after a few months, got married in Miami, and moved.

persons.name: Maria
persons.context: Epstein's girlfriend, 19 years old when the client met her. Introduced to Epstein by Jean Luc Brunel. Lived at an Epstein-owned apartment and remained his girlfriend through approximately 2007.

persons.name: Chloe
persons.context: Epstein's second girlfriend, a 21-year-old professional model in 2005. Lived with Epstein until 2006 when she was in a vehicle accident.

persons.name: Lynn
persons.context: A person at Epstein's residence who greeted the client and said 'Give me 5 minutes I will show you upstairs' to the massage room.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pop
persons.context: Author of the attorney proffer letter, representing an unnamed client who was a victim of Jeffrey Epstein's manipulation.

connections.description: Close friends for over 10 years; Brunel lived in Epstein-owned apartments and was involved in modeling agencies, potentially sourcing models.
Maxwell described as the 'original girl finder' who helped coordinate supplies and intimidated younger women; a key associate in Epstein's operations.
Groff was Epstein's executive secretary and right hand, managing his schedule, calls, and travel; described as invaluable.
Nadia was Epstein's personal assistant, handling travel and logistics; the client believes she might be a victim.
Friends since the 1990s; Kates owned Next Model Management and introduced the client to Epstein. Epstein asked her to introduce him to girls.
Ex-girlfriend; Epstein cared for her and her daughter (his goddaughter). He visited her before incarceration.
Epstein's girlfriend, introduced by Jean Luc Brunel; lived in an Epstein-owned apartment.
Epstein's second girlfriend, a professional model who lived with him until a 2006 accident.
Brunel introduced Maria to Jeffrey Epstein.
Eva Dubin introduced Adriana to Jeffrey Epstein.
Pop is the attorney for a client who was a victim of Epstein, writing a proffer detailing Epstein's alleged crimes against his client.
Epstein is described as the perpetrator who manipulated, controlled, and sexually exploited the attorney's client and other young women.

events.title: Client's First Meeting with Epstein
events.description: The client went to Epstein's residence for the first time, gave him a massage during which he masturbated, and was asked to return.

events.title: Beginning of Sexual Use of Toys
events.description: Epstein began using sexual toys such as vibrators on the client during their encounters.

events.title: Introduction of Threesomes
events.description: Epstein suggested and engaged in threesomes with the client and other women, including his girlfriends, in New York, New Mexico, and on the island.

events.title: Client Directed to Epstein's Friends
events.description: Epstein directed the client to go to hotel rooms to give massages or 'be with' his male friends, which occurred approximately every three months.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest Revealed
events.description: Epstein told the client he had been arrested and the FBI was involved, instructing her to stop bringing girls. This limited her access to him.

events.title: FBI Visit to Epstein's Apartments
events.description: The client heard that the FBI went to the Street address where Brazilian models brought by Jean Luc Brunel were staying.

events.title: Client Internship at NEXT Model Management
events.description: Epstein placed the client as an intern at Faith Kates's Next Model Management in New York, where she worked until February 2007.

events.title: Client Starts Job at Smith Barney
events.description: Epstein secured a job for the client at Smith Barney, which she started in February 2007 and left in May 2008 due to personal reasons and Epstein's notoriety.

events.title: Post-Incarceration Contact
events.description: The client spoke to Epstein by telephone in New York; he asked her to look for girls again, but she declined, leading her to decide to leave New York.

events.title: Epstein Warns of Lawsuit
events.description: Epstein emailed the client stating she had been named in a lawsuit (Doe 43 v. Epstein et al.) and advised her to get an attorney, suggesting they cease communication.

events.title: Attorney Proffer Submission
events.description: Attorney Jeffrey S. Pop submits a detailed proffer letter outlining his client's account of Jeffrey Epstein's methods of manipulation and exploitation.

locations: Little St. James Island (U.S. Virgin Islands)
keyFacts: The client's relationship with Jeffrey Epstein began on April 19, 2004, after being recruited via Mila and Barbara, with the understanding he paid $300 for topless massages ending in masturbation.
Epstein pressured the client to introduce other girls to him, a request that became more insistent over time, and he was known to see girls for massages up to three times a day in New York.

Epstein's inner circle included Ghislaine Maxwell (described as the 'original girl finder'), Jean Luc Brunel (modeling agency owner), and several employees like Sarah Groff and Nadia who managed his logistics.
The client describes escalating sexual abuse, including the use of toys, threesomes with Epstein's girlfriends, and being directed to provide massages or sexual services to Epstein's male friends.

Epstein provided the client with financial support, dental work, and later secured her employment as an intern at Next Model Management and a job at Smith Barney, illustrating a pattern of control through economic means.
The document is an attorney proffer detailing a systematic 16-point method allegedly used by Jeffrey Epstein to manipulate, sexually exploit, and control young women.
Epstein's methods included gaining trust, creating an aura of privilege, increasing financial dependency, introducing group sex and sexual devices, and directing encounters with his 'friends'.
Girls were reportedly discarded around age 27 if they became 'unstable or unwilling to bear fruit (more introductions)'.
The proffer states that the attorney's client continues to suffer psychologically and emotionally over 15 years later from Epstein's control and domination.
